stem: The intensive care nurse is managing a client with severe ARDS. Based on the documentation in the Respiratory Mechanics Log, match each ventilator strategy with the appropriate clinical objective.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
08:00: Client (48-year-old male) with Multi-Organ Dysfunction Syndrome (MODS) and ARDS.
08:30: High plateau pressures noted (> 35 cm H2O).
09:00: Switched from traditional volume control to Lung-Protective Ventilation (LPV).
09:30: Goal set for 'Permissive Hypercapnia' to avoid barotrauma.

tabs.title: Respiratory Mechanics Log
tabs.content:
StrategyCurrent SettingObjective
Tidal Volume4 mL/kg (Initial 10)Reduce lung stretch
PEEP15 cm H2OAlveolar recruitment
Plateau PressureTarget < 30 cm H2OAvoid VILI
pH Goal7.20 - 7.30Permissive Hypercapnia

tabs.title: ABG Stats
tabs.content: pH 7.24, PaCO2 58 mmHg, PaO2 62 mmHg, HCO3 24 mEq/L. P/F Ratio 68.

columns.text: Accepting Acidemia to Avoid High Pressures
Maximizing Surface Area for Gas Exchange

rationale.correct: Low tidal volumes (r1) prevent the lungs from over-stretching (volutrauma/c1). Permissive hypercapnia (r2) is the intentional acceptance of high CO2/low pH to avoid using dangerous pressures (c2). High PEEP (r3) creates an 'Open Lung' by recruiting alveoli (c3). Maintaining plateau pressures < 30 cm H2O (r4) is the hallmark of preventing barotrauma (c4).
clinicalPearls: Traditional ventilation (10-15 mL/kg) is potentially harmful in ARDS.
Lungs in ARDS are described as 'Baby Lungs' because only a small portion of the lung is actually functional.
Permissive hypercapnia is contraindicated in patients with elevated intracranial pressure (ICP).

questionTrap.trap: Believing that the nurse should increase the respiratory rate in response to a PaCO2 of 58 mmHg in an ARDS patient.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the goal is 'Permissive Hypercapnia', an elevated PaCO2 is expected and accepted as long as the pH does not decrease too low (< 7.15-7.20).

mnemonic.title: Protect the Plate
mnemonic.expansion: Keep the **Plateau** pressure under **30 cm H2O** to protect the lung plate (parenchyma).
